revision.text:
{{classical mechanics|expanded=formulations}} [[file:Edward J Routh.jpg|thumb|150px|[[Edward John Routh]], 1831–1907.]]
In [[analytical mechanics]], a branch of [[theoretical physics]], '''Routhian mechanics''' is a hybrid formulation of [[Lagrangian mechanics]] and [[Hamiltonian mechanics]] developed by [[Edward John Routh]]. Correspondingly, the '''Routhian''' is the [[function (mathematics)|function]] which replaces both the [[Lagrangian mechanics|Lagrangian]] and [[Hamiltonian function|Hamiltonian]] functions.
The Routhian, like the Hamiltonian, can be obtained from a [[Legendre transform]] of the Lagrangian, and has a similar mathematical form to the Hamiltonian, but is not exactly the same. The difference between the Lagrangian, Hamiltonian, and Routhian functions are their variables. For a given set of [[generalized coordinates]] representing the [[degrees of freedom (physics and chemistry)|degrees of freedom]] in the system, the Lagrangian is a function of the coordinates and velocities, while the Hamiltonian is a function of the coordinates and momenta.
The Routhian differs from these functions in that some coordinates are chosen to have corresponding generalized velocities, the rest to have corresponding generalized momenta. This choice is arbitrary, and can be done to simplify the problem. It also has the consequence that the '''Routhian equations''' are exactly the Hamiltonian equations for some coordinates and corresponding momenta, and the Lagrangian equations for the rest of the coordinates and their velocities. In each case the Lagrangian and Hamiltonian functions are replaced by a single function, the Routhian. The full set thus has the advantages of both sets of equations, with the convenience of splitting one set of coordinates to the Hamilton equations, and the rest to the Lagrangian equations.
Often the Routhian approach may offer no advantage, but one notable case where this is useful is when a system has [[cyclic coordinates]] (also called "ignorable coordinates"), by definition those coordinates which do not appear in the original Lagrangian. The Lagrangian equations are powerful results, used frequently in theory and practice, since the equations of motion in the coordinates are easy to set up. However, if cyclic coordinates occur there will still be equations to solve for all the coordinates, including the cyclic coordinates despite their absence in the Lagrangian. The Hamiltonian equations are useful theoretical results, but less useful in practice because coordinates and momenta are related together in the solutions - after solving the equations the coordinates and momenta must be eliminated from each other. Nevertheless, the Hamiltonian equations are perfectly suited to cyclic coordinates because the equations in the cyclic coordinates trivially vanish, leaving only the equations in the non cyclic coordinates.
The Routhian approach has the best of both approaches, because cyclic coordinates can be split off to the Hamiltonian equations and eliminated, leaving behind the non cyclic coordinates to be solved from the Lagrangian equations. Overall fewer equations need to be solved compared to the Lagrangian approach.
As with the rest of analytical mechanics, Routhian mechanics is completely equivalent to Newtonian mechanics, all other formulations of classical mechanics, and introduces no new physics. It offers an alternative way to solve mechanical problems.
==Definitions==
In the case of Lagrangian mechanics, the [[generalized coordinates]] {{math|''q''<sub>1</sub>, ''q''<sub>2</sub>}}, ... and the corresponding velocities {{math|''dq''<sub>1</sub>/''dt'', ''dq''<sub>2</sub>/''dt'', ...}}, and possibly time<ref group=nb>The coordinates are functions of time, so the Lagrangian always has implicit time-dependence via the coordinates. If the Lagrangian changes with time irrespective of the coordinates, usually due to some time-dependent potential, then the Lagrangian is said to have "explicit" time-dependence. Similarly for the Hamiltonian and Routhian functions.</ref> {{math|''t''}}, enter the Lagrangian,
:<math>L(q_1,q_2,\ldots,\dot{q}_1,\dot{q}_2,\ldots,t)\,, \quad \dot{q}_i = \frac{d q_i}{dt} \,, </math>
where the overdots denote [[time derivative]]s.
In Hamiltonian mechanics, the generalized coordinates {{math|''q''<sub>1</sub>, ''q''<sub>2</sub>, ...}} and the corresponding generalized momenta {{math|''p''<sub>1</sub>, ''p''<sub>2</sub>, ...,}} and possibly time, enter the Hamiltonian,
:<math>H(q_1,q_2,\ldots,p_1,p_2,\ldots,t) = \sum_i \dot{q}_ip_i - L(q_1,q_2,\ldots,\dot{q}_1(p_1),\dot{q}_2(p_2),\ldots,t) \,, \quad p_i = \frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{q}_i}\,,</math>
where the second equation is the definition of the generalized momentum {{math|''p<sub>i</sub>''}} corresponding to the coordinate {{math|''q<sub>i</sub>''}} ([[partial derivative]]s are denoted using {{math|∂}}). The velocities {{math|''dq<sub>i</sub>''/''dt''}} are expressed as functions of their corresponding momenta by inverting their defining relation. In this context, {{math|''p<sub>i</sub>''}} is said to be the momentum "canonically conjugate" to {{math|''q<sub>i</sub>''}}.
The Routhian is intermediate between {{math|''L''}} and {{math|''H''}}; some coordinates {{math|''q''<sub>1</sub>, ''q''<sub>2</sub>, ..., ''q''<sub>''n''</sub>}} are chosen to have corresponding generalized momenta {{math|''p''<sub>1</sub>, ''p''<sub>2</sub>, ..., ''p''<sub>''n''</sub>}}, the rest of the coordinates {{math|''ζ''<sub>1</sub>, ''ζ''<sub>2</sub>, ..., ''ζ<sub>s</sub>''}} to have generalized velocities {{math|''dζ''<sub>1</sub>/''dt'', ''dζ''<sub>2</sub>/''dt'', ..., ''dζ<sub>s</sub>''/''dt''}}, and time may appear explicitly;<ref>{{harvnb|Goldstein|1980|page=352}}</ref><ref>{{harvnb|Landau|Lifshitz|1976|page=134}}</ref>
{{equation box 1 |indent = : |background colour = white |border colour =black |border = 1 |title = '''Routhian''' ({{math|''n'' + ''s''}} degrees of freedom) |equation=<math>R(q_1,\ldots,q_n,\zeta_1,\ldots,\zeta_s, p_1, \ldots,p_n , \dot{\zeta}_1 , \ldots,\dot{\zeta}_s,t) = \sum_{i=1}^n p_i\dot{q}_i(p_i) - L(q_1,\ldots,q_n,\zeta_1,\ldots,\zeta_s, \dot{q}_1(p_1), \ldots, \dot{q}_n(p_n) , \dot{\zeta}_1 , \ldots,\dot{\zeta}_s,t) \,, </math> }}
where again the generalized velocity {{math|''dq''<sub>''i''</sub>/''dt''}} is to be expressed as a function of generalized momentum {{math|''p<sub>i</sub>''}} via its defining relation. The choice of which {{math|''n''}} coordinates are to have corresponding momenta, out of the {{math|''n'' + ''s''}} coordinates, is arbitrary.
The above is used by [[course of theoretical physics|Landau and Lifshitz]], and [[Classical Mechanics (Goldstein book)|Goldstein]]. Some authors may define the Routhian to be the negative of the above definition.<ref>{{harvnb|Hand|Finch|2008|page=23}}</ref>
Given the length of the general definition, a more compact notation is to use boldface for [[tuple]]s (or vectors) of the variables, thus {{math|'''q''' {{=}} (''q''<sub>1</sub>, ''q''<sub>2</sub>, ..., ''q<sub>n</sub>'')}}, {{math|'''ζ''' {{=}} (''ζ''<sub>1</sub>, ''ζ''<sub>2</sub>, ..., ''ζ<sub>s</sub>'')}}, {{math|'''p''' {{=}} (''p''<sub>1</sub>, ''p''<sub>2</sub>, ..., ''p<sub>n</sub>'')}}, and {{math|''d'' '''ζ'''/''dt'' {{=}} (''dζ''<sub>1</sub>/''dt'', ''dζ''<sub>2</sub>/''dt'', ..., ''dζ<sub>s</sub>''/''dt'')}}, so that
:<math>R(\mathbf{q},\boldsymbol{\zeta}, \mathbf{p}, \dot{\boldsymbol{\zeta}}, t) = \mathbf{p}\cdot\dot{{\mathbf{q}}} - L(\mathbf{q}, \boldsymbol{\zeta}, \dot{\mathbf{q}}, \dot{\boldsymbol{\zeta}},t) \,, </math>
where · is the [[dot product]] defined on the tuples, for the specific example appearing here:
:<math>\mathbf{p}\cdot\dot{{\mathbf{q}}} = \sum_{i=1}^n p_i\dot{q}_i \,.</math>
==Equations of motion==
For reference, the [[Lagrangian mechanics|Lagrangian equations]] for {{math|''s''}} degrees of freedom are a set of {{math|''s''}} coupled second order [[ordinary differential equation]]s in the coordinates
:<math>\frac{d}{dt}\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{q}_j} = \frac{\partial L}{\partial q_j} \,, </math>
where {{math|''j'' {{=}} 1, 2, ..., ''s''}}, and the [[Hamiltonian mechanics|Hamiltonian equations]] for {{math|''n''}} degrees of freedom are a set of {{math|2''n''}} coupled first order ordinary differential equations in the coordinates and momenta
:<math>\dot{q}_i = \frac{\partial H}{\partial p_i} \,,\quad \dot{p}_i = -\frac{\partial H}{\partial q_i} \,. </math>
Below, the Routhian equations of motion are obtained in two ways, in the process other useful derivatives are found that can be used elsewhere.
===Two degrees of freedom===
Consider the case of a system with two [[degrees of freedom (physics and chemistry)|degrees of freedom]], {{math|''q''}} and {{math|''ζ''}}, with generalized velocities {{math|''dq''/''dt''}} and {{math|''dζ''/''dt''}}, and the Lagrangian is time-dependent. (The generalization to any number of degrees of freedom follows exactly the same procedure as with two).<ref>{{harvnb|Landau|Lifshitz|1976|page=134}}</ref> The Lagrangian of the system will have the form
:<math> L(q, \zeta, \dot{q}, \dot{\zeta}, t) </math>
The [[differential of a function|differential]] of {{math|''L''}} is
:<math> dL = \frac{\partial L}{\partial q}dq + \frac{\partial L}{\partial \zeta}d\zeta + \frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{q}}d\dot{q} + \frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{\zeta}}d\dot{\zeta} + \frac{\partial L}{\partial t}dt \,. </math>
Now change variables, from the set ({{math|''q''}}, {{math|''ζ''}}, {{math|''dq''/''dt''}}, {{math|''dζ''/''dt''}}) to ({{math|''q''}}, {{math|''ζ''}}, {{math|''p''}}, {{math|''dζ''/''dt''}}), simply switching the velocity {{math|''dq''/''dt''}} to the momentum {{math|''p''}}. This change of variables in the differentials is the [[Legendre transformation]]. The differential of the new function to replace {{math|''L''}} will be a sum of differentials in {{math|''dq''}}, {{math|''dζ''}}, {{math|''dp''}}, {{math|''d''(''dζ''/''dt'')}}, and {{math|''dt''}}. Using the definition of generalized momentum and Lagrange's equation for the coordinate {{math|''q''}}:
:<math>p = \frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{q}} \,,\quad \dot{p} = \frac{d}{dt}\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{q}} = \frac{\partial L}{\partial q}</math>
we have
:<math> dL = \dot{p}dq + \frac{\partial L}{\partial \zeta}d\zeta + p d\dot{q} + \frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{\zeta}}d\dot{\zeta} + \frac{\partial L}{\partial t}dt </math>
and to replace {{math|''pd''(''dq''/''dt'')}} by {{math|(''dq''/''dt'')''dp''}}, recall the [[product rule]] for differentials,<ref group=nb>For two functions {{math|''u''}} and {{math|''v''}}, the differential of the product is {{math|''d''(''uv'') {{=}} ''udv'' + ''vdu''}}.</ref> and substitute
:<math> pd\dot{q} = d(\dot{q} p) - \dot{q}dp </math>
to obtain the differential of a new function in terms of the new set of variables:
:<math> d(L-p\dot{q}) = \dot{p} dq + \frac{\partial L}{\partial \zeta}d\zeta - \dot{q} dp + \frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{\zeta}}d\dot{\zeta} + \frac{\partial L}{\partial t}dt \,. </math>
Introducing the Routhian
:<math> R(q,\zeta,p,\dot{\zeta},t) = p \dot{q}(p) - L </math>
where again the velocity {{math|''dq''/''dt''}} is a function of the momentum {{math|''p''}}, we have
:<math> dR = -\dot{p} dq - \frac{\partial L}{\partial \zeta}d\zeta + \dot{q}dp - \frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{\zeta}}d\dot{\zeta} - \frac{\partial L}{\partial t}dt\,, </math>
but from the above definition, the differential of the Routhian is
:<math> dR = \frac{\partial R }{\partial q}dq + \frac{\partial R }{\partial \zeta}d\zeta + \frac{\partial R }{\partial p}dp + \frac{\partial R }{\partial \dot{\zeta}}d\dot{\zeta} + \frac{\partial R}{\partial t}dt \,.</math>
Comparing the coefficients of the differentials {{math|''dq''}}, {{math|''dζ''}}, {{math|''dp''}}, {{math|''d''(''dζ''/''dt'')}}, and {{math|''dt''}}, the results are [[Hamiltonian mechanics|Hamilton's equations]] for the coordinate {{math|''q''}},
:<math> \dot{q} = \frac{\partial R}{\partial p} \,,\quad \dot{p} = -\frac{\partial R}{\partial q} \,,</math>
and [[Lagrange's equation]] for the coordinate {{math|''ζ''}}
:<math>\frac{d}{dt}\frac{\partial R}{\partial \dot{\zeta}} = \frac{\partial R}{\partial \zeta} </math>
which follow from
:<math> \frac{\partial L}{\partial \zeta} = - \frac{\partial R}{\partial \zeta} \,,\quad \frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{\zeta}} = - \frac{\partial R}{\partial \dot{\zeta}} \,, </math>
and taking the total time derivative of the second equation and equating to the first. Notice the Routhian replaces the Hamiltonian and Lagrangian functions in all the equations of motion.
The remaining equation states the partial time derivatives of {{math|''L''}} and {{math|''R''}} are negatives
:<math>\frac{\partial L}{\partial t}=-\frac{\partial R}{\partial t}\,.</math>
===Any number of degrees of freedom===
For {{math|''n'' + ''s''}} coordinates as defined above, with Routhian
:<math>R(q_1,\ldots,q_n,\zeta_1,\ldots,\zeta_s, p_1, \ldots,p_n , \dot{\zeta}_1 , \ldots,\dot{\zeta}_s,t) = \sum_{i=1}^n p_i\dot{q}_i(p_i) - L</math>
the equations of motion can be derived by a Legendre transformation of this Routhian as in the previous section, but another way is to simply take the partial derivatives of {{math|''R''}} with respect to the coordinates {{math|''q<sub>i</sub>''}} and {{math|''ζ<sub>j</sub>''}}, momenta {{math|''p<sub>i</sub>''}}, and velocities {{math|''dζ<sub>j</sub>''/''dt''}}, where {{math|''i'' {{=}} 1, 2, ..., ''n''}}, and {{math|''j'' {{=}} 1, 2, ..., ''s''}}. The derivatives are
:<math> \frac{\partial R}{\partial q_i} = -\frac{\partial L}{\partial q_i} = - \frac{d}{dt}\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{q}_i} = - \dot{p}_i </math>
:<math> \frac{\partial R}{\partial p_i} = \dot{q}_i </math>
:<math> \frac{\partial R}{\partial \zeta_j} = - \frac{\partial L}{\partial \zeta_j} \,, </math>
:<math> \frac{\partial R}{\partial \dot{\zeta}_j} = - \frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{\zeta}_j} \,, </math>
:<math> \frac{\partial R}{\partial t} = - \frac{\partial L}{\partial t} \,. </math>
The first two are identically the Hamiltonian equations. Equating the total time derivative of the fourth set of equations with the third (for each value of {{math|''j''}}) gives the Lagrangian equations. The fifth is just the same relation between time partial derivatives as before. To summarize<ref>{{harvnb|Goldstein|1980|page=352}}</ref>
{{equation box 1 |indent = : |background colour = white |border colour =black |border = 1 |title = '''Routhian equations of motion''' (''n'' + ''s'' degrees of freedom) |equation=<math> \dot{q}_i = \frac{\partial R}{\partial p_i} \,,\quad \dot{p}_i = -\frac{\partial R}{\partial q_i} \,, </math>
<math>\frac{d}{dt}\frac{\partial R}{\partial \dot{\zeta}_j} = \frac{\partial R}{\partial \zeta_j} \,. </math> }}
The total number of equations is {{math|2''n'' + ''s''}}, there are {{math|2''n''}} Hamiltonian equations plus {{math|''s''}} Lagrange equations.
==Energy==
Since the Lagrangian has the same units as [[energy]], the units of the Routhian are also energy. In [[SI units]] this is the [[Joule]].
Taking the total time derivative of the Lagrangian leads to the general result
:<math>\frac{\partial L}{\partial t} = \frac{d }{d t}\left(\sum_{i=1}^n \dot{q}_i\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{q}_i} + \sum_{j=1}^s \dot{\zeta}_j\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{\zeta}_j} - L\right)\,.</math>
If the Lagrangian is independent of time, the partial time derivative of the Lagrangian is zero, {{math|∂''L''/∂''t'' {{=}} 0}}, so the quantity under the total time derivative in brackets must be a constant, it is the total energy of the system<ref>{{harvnb|Landau|Lifshitz|1976|page=134}}</ref>
:<math>E = \sum_{i=1}^n \dot{q}_i\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{q}_i} + \sum_{j=1}^s \dot{\zeta}_j\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{\zeta}_j} - L\,.</math>
(If there are external fields interacting with the constituents of the system, they can vary throughout space but not time). This expression requires the partial derivatives of {{math|''L''}} with respect to ''all'' the velocities {{math|''dq<sub>i</sub>''/''dt''}} and {{math|''dζ<sub>j</sub>''/''dt''}}. Under the same condition of {{math|''R''}} being time independent, the energy in terms of the Routhian is a little simpler, substituting the definition of {{math|''R''}} and the partial derivatives of {{math|''R''}} with respect to the velocities {{math|''dζ<sub>j</sub>''/''dt''}},
:<math>E = R - \sum_{j=1}^s \dot{\zeta}_j\frac{\partial R}{\partial \dot{\zeta}_j} \,.</math>
Notice only the partial derivatives of {{math|''R''}} with respect to the velocities {{math|''dζ<sub>j</sub>''/''dt''}} are needed. In the case that {{math|''s'' {{=}} 0}} and the Routhian is explicitly time-independent, then {{math|''E'' {{=}} ''R''}}, that is, the Routhian equals the energy of the system. The same expression for {{math|''R''}} in when {{math|''s'' {{=}} 0}} is also the Hamiltonian, so in all {{math|''E'' {{=}} ''R'' {{=}} ''H''}}.
If the Routhian has explicit time dependence, the total energy of the system is not constant. The general result is
:<math>\frac{\partial R}{\partial t} = \dfrac{d}{dt}\left(R - \sum_{j=1}^s \dot{\zeta}_j\frac{\partial R}{\partial \dot{\zeta}_j} \right)\,,</math>
which can be derived from the total time derivative of {{math|''R''}} in the same way as for {{math|''L''}}.
==Cyclic coordinates==
The Routhian formulation is useful for systems with [[cyclic coordinates]], because by definition those coordinates do not enter {{math|''L''}}, and hence {{math|''R''}}. The corresponding partial derivatives of {{math|''L''}} and {{math|''R''}} with respect to those coordinates are zero, which equates to the corresponding generalized momenta reducing to constants. To make this concrete, if the {{math|''q<sub>i</sub>''}} are all cyclic coordinates, and the {{math|''ζ<sub>j</sub>''}} are all non cyclic, then
:<math>\frac{\partial L}{\partial q_i} = \dot{p}_i = - \frac{\partial R}{\partial q_i} = 0 \quad \Rightarrow \quad p_i = \alpha_i \,, </math>
where the {{math|''α<sub>i</sub>''}} are constants. With these constants substituted into the Routhian, {{math|''R''}} is a function of only the non cyclic coordinates and velocities (and in general time also)
:<math>R(\zeta_1,\ldots,\zeta_s,\alpha_1,\ldots,\alpha_n,\dot{\zeta}_1,\ldots,\dot{\zeta}_s,t) = \sum_{i=1}^n \alpha_i\dot{q}_i(\alpha_i) - L(\zeta_1,\ldots,\zeta_s,\dot{q}_1(\alpha_1),\ldots,\dot{q}_n(\alpha_n),\dot{\zeta}_1,\ldots,\dot{\zeta}_s,t) \,, </math>
The {{math|2''n''}} Hamiltonian equation in the cyclic coordinates automatically vanishes,
:<math>\dot{q}_i=\frac{\partial R}{\partial \alpha_i}=f_i( \zeta_1(t),\ldots,\zeta_s(t), \dot{\zeta}_1(t),\ldots,\dot{\zeta}_s(t), \alpha_1,\ldots,\alpha_n,t) \,,\quad \dot{p}_i=-\frac{\partial R}{\partial q_i}=0\,,</math>
and the {{math|''s''}} Lagrangian equations are in the non cyclic coordinates
:<math>\frac{d}{dt}\frac{\partial R}{\partial \dot{\zeta}_j} = \frac{\partial R}{\partial \zeta_j} \,. </math>
Thus the problem has been reduced to solving the Lagrangian equations in the non cyclic coordinates, with the advantage of the Hamiltonian equations cleanly removing the cyclic coordinates. Using those solutions, the equations for <math>\dot{q}_i</math>can be integrated to compute <math>q_i(t)</math>.
If we are interested in how the cyclic coordinates change with time, the equations for the generalized velocities corresponding to the cyclic coordinates can be integrated.
==Examples==
The Routhian method does not guarantee the equations of motion will be simple, however it will lead to fewer equations.
=== Central potential in spherical coordinates ===
One general class of mechanical systems with cyclic coordinates are those with [[central potential]]s, because potentials of this form only have dependence on radial separations and no dependence on angles.
Consider a particle of mass {{math|''m''}} under the influence of a central potential {{math|''V''(''r'')}} in [[spherical polar coordinates]] {{math|(''r'', ''θ'', ''φ'')}}
:<math>L(r,\dot{r},\theta,\dot{\theta},\dot{\phi}) = \frac{m}{2}(\dot{r}^2 + {r}^2\dot{\theta}^2 + r^2 \sin^2\theta\dot{\phi}^2) - V(r) \,. </math>
Notice {{math|''φ''}} is cyclic, because it does not appear in the Lagrangian. The momentum conjugate to {{math|''φ''}} is the constant
:<math>p_\phi = \frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{\phi}} = mr^2\sin^2\theta\dot{\phi}\,,</math>
in which {{math|''r''}} and {{math|''dφ''/''dt''}} can vary with time, but the angular momentum {{math|''p<sub>φ</sub>''}} is constant. The Routhian can be taken to be
:<math>\begin{align} R(r,\dot{r},\theta,\dot{\theta}) & = p_\phi\dot{\phi} - L \\ & = p_\phi\dot{\phi} - \frac{m}{2}\dot{r}^2 - \frac{m}{2}r^2\dot{\theta}^2 - \frac{p_\phi\dot{\phi}}{2} + V(r) \\ & = \frac{p_\phi\dot{\phi}}{2} - \frac{m}{2}\dot{r}^2 - \frac{m}{2}r^2\dot{\theta}^2 + V(r) \\ & = \frac{p_\phi^2 }{2mr^2\sin^2\theta} - \frac{m}{2}\dot{r}^2 - \frac{m}{2}r^2\dot{\theta}^2 + V(r) \,. \end{align}</math>
We can solve for {{math|''r''}} and {{math|''θ''}} using Lagrange's equations, and do not need to solve for {{math|''φ''}} since it is eliminated by Hamiltonian's equations. The {{math|''r''}} equation is
:<math>\frac{d}{dt} \frac{\partial R}{\partial \dot{r}} = \frac{\partial R}{\partial r} \quad\Rightarrow\quad-m\ddot{r} = -\frac{p_\phi^2}{mr^3\sin^2\theta} - mr\dot{\theta}^2 + \frac{\partial V}{\partial r} \,, </math>
and the {{math|''θ''}} equation is
:<math>\frac{d}{dt} \frac{\partial R}{\partial \dot{\theta}} = \frac{\partial R}{\partial \theta} \quad\Rightarrow\quad -m(2r\dot{r}\dot{\theta} + r^2\ddot{\theta}) = -\frac{p_\phi^2\cos\theta}{mr^2\sin^3\theta} \,. </math>
The Routhian approach has obtained two coupled nonlinear equations. By contrast the Lagrangian approach leads to ''three'' nonlinear coupled equations, mixing in the first and second time derivatives of {{math|''φ''}} in all of them, despite its absence from the Lagrangian.
The {{math|''r''}} equation is
:<math>\frac{d}{dt} \frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{r}} = \frac{\partial L}{\partial r} \quad\Rightarrow\quad m\ddot{r} = mr\dot{\theta}^2 + mr\sin^2\theta\dot{\phi}^2 - \frac{\partial V}{\partial r} \,,</math>
the {{math|''θ''}} equation is
:<math>\frac{d}{dt} \frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{\theta}} = \frac{\partial L}{\partial \theta} \quad\Rightarrow\quad 2r\dot{r}\dot{\theta} + r^2\ddot{\theta} = r^2 \sin\theta\cos\theta\dot{\phi}^2\,, </math>
the {{math|''φ''}} equation is
:<math>\frac{d}{dt} \frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{\phi}} = \frac{\partial L}{\partial \phi} \quad\Rightarrow\quad 2r\dot{r}\sin^2\theta\dot{\phi} + 2r^2 \sin\theta\cos\theta \dot{\theta}\dot{\phi} + r^2\sin^2\theta \ddot{\phi}=0 \,. </math>
===Symmetric mechanical systems===
====Spherical pendulum====
[[File:Spherical pendulum Lagrangian mechanics.svg|thumb|300px|Spherical pendulum: angles and velocities.]]
Consider the [[spherical pendulum]], a mass {{math|''m''}} (known as a "pendulum bob") attached to a rigid rod of length {{math|''l''}} of negligible mass, subject to a local gravitational field {{math|''g''}}. The system rotates with angular velocity {{math|''dφ''/''dt''}} which is ''not'' constant. The angle between the rod and vertical is {{math|''θ''}} and is ''not'' constant.
The Lagrangian is<ref group=nb>The potential energy is actually :<math>V=mg\ell(1-\cos\theta)\,,</math> but since the first term is constant, it can be ignored in the Lagrangian (and Routhian) which only depend on derivatives of coordinates and velocities. Subtracting this from the kinetic energy means a plus sign in the Lagrangian, not minus.</ref>
:<math>L(\theta,\dot{\theta},\dot{\phi}) = \frac{m\ell^2}{2}(\dot{\theta}^2 + \sin^2\theta \dot{\phi}^2) + mg\ell\cos\theta \,, </math>
and {{math|''φ''}} is the cyclic coordinate for the system with constant momentum
:<math>p_\phi = \frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{\phi}} = m\ell^2\sin^2\theta \dot{\phi} \,. </math>
which again is physically the angular momentum of the system about the vertical. The angle {{math|''θ''}} and angular velocity {{math|''dφ''/''dt''}} vary with time, but the angular momentum is constant. The Routhian is
:<math>\begin{align} R(\theta,\dot{\theta}) & = p_\phi \dot{\phi} - L \\ & = p_\phi \dot{\phi} - \frac{m\ell^2}{2}\dot{\theta}^2 - \frac{p_\phi \dot{\phi}}{2} - mg\ell\cos\theta \\ & = \frac{p_\phi \dot{\phi}}{2} - \frac{m\ell^2}{2}\dot{\theta}^2 - mg\ell\cos\theta \\ & = \frac{p_\phi^2 }{2m\ell^2\sin^2\theta} - \frac{m\ell^2}{2}\dot{\theta}^2 - mg\ell\cos\theta \end{align}</math>
The {{math|''θ''}} equation is found from the Lagrangian equations
:<math>\frac{d}{dt}\frac{\partial R}{\partial \dot{\theta}} = \frac{\partial R}{\partial \theta} \quad \Rightarrow \quad - m\ell^2\ddot{\theta} = -\frac{p_\phi^2 \cos\theta}{m\ell^2\sin^3\theta} + mg\ell\sin\theta \,,</math>
or simplifying by introducing the constants
:<math>a = \frac{p_\phi^2}{m^2\ell^4}\,,\quad b = \frac{g}{\ell} \,,</math>
gives
:<math>\ddot{\theta} = a\frac{\cos\theta}{\sin^3\theta} - b \sin\theta \,.</math>
This equation resembles the simple nonlinear [[pendulum equation]], because it can swing through the vertical axis, with an additional term to account for the rotation about the vertical axis (the constant {{math|''a''}} is related to the angular momentum {{math|''p<sub>φ</sub>''}}).
Applying the Lagrangian approach there are two nonlinear coupled equations to solve.
The {{math|''θ''}} equation is
:<math>\frac{d}{dt} \frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{\theta}} = \frac{\partial L}{\partial \theta} \quad\Rightarrow\quad m\ell^2\ddot{\theta} = m\ell^2 \sin\theta\cos\theta\dot{\phi}^2 -mg\ell\sin\theta \,, </math>
and the {{math|''φ''}} equation is
:<math>\frac{d}{dt} \frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{\phi}} = \frac{\partial L}{\partial \phi} \quad\Rightarrow\quad 2\sin\theta\cos\theta \dot{\theta}\dot{\phi} + \sin^2\theta \ddot{\phi}=0 \,. </math>
====Heavy symmetrical top====
[[File:Heavy symmetric top euler angles.svg|thumb|Heavy symmetric top in terms of the Euler angles.]]
The heavy [[symmetrical top]] of mass {{math|''M''}} has Lagrangian<ref>{{harvnb|Goldstein|1980|page=214}}</ref><ref>{{harvnb|Kibble|Berkshire|2004|page=236}}</ref>
:<math>L(\theta,\dot{\theta},\dot{\psi},\dot{\phi})=\frac{I_1}{2}(\dot{\theta}^2 + \dot{\phi}^2\sin^2\theta) + \frac{I_3}{2}(\dot{\psi}^2+\dot{\phi}^2\cos^2\theta)+I_3\dot{\psi}\dot{\phi}\cos\theta-Mg\ell\cos\theta</math>
where {{math|''ψ'', ''φ'', ''θ''}} are the [[Euler angles]], {{math|''θ''}} is the angle between the vertical {{math|''z''}}-axis and the top's {{math|''z''′}}-axis, {{math|''ψ''}} is the rotation of the top about its own {{math|''z''′}}-axis, and {{math|''φ''}} the azimuthal of the top's {{math|''z''′}}-axis around the vertical {{math|''z''}}-axis. The principal [[moments of inertia]] are {{math|''I''<sub>1</sub>}} about the top's own {{math|''x''′}} axis, {{math|''I''<sub>2</sub>}} about the top's own {{math|''y''′}} axes, and {{math|''I''<sub>3</sub>}} about the top's own {{math|''z''′}}-axis. Since the top is symmetric about its {{math|''z''′}}-axis, {{math|''I''<sub>1</sub> {{=}} ''I''<sub>2</sub>}}. Here the simple relation for local [[gravitational potential energy]] {{math|''V'' {{=}} ''Mgl''cos''θ''}} is used where {{math|''g''}} is the acceleration due to gravity, and the centre of mass of the top is a distance {{math|''l''}} from its tip along its {{math|''z''′}}-axis.
The angles {{math|''ψ'', ''φ''}} are cyclic. The constant momenta are the angular momenta of the top about its axis and its precession about the vertical, respectively:
:<math>p_\psi = \frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{\psi}} = I_3\dot{\psi} + I_3\dot{\phi} \cos\theta </math> :<math>p_\phi = \frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{\phi}} = \dot{\phi}(I_1\sin^2\theta + I_3\cos^2\theta) + I_3\dot{\psi}\cos\theta </math>
From these, eliminating {{math|''dψ''/''dt''}}:
:<math>p_\phi - p_\psi\cos\theta = I_1\dot{\phi}\sin^2\theta</math>
we have
:<math> \dot{\phi} = \frac{p_\phi - p_\psi\cos\theta}{I_1\sin^2\theta}\,, </math>
and to eliminate {{math|''dφ''/''dt''}}, substitute this result into {{math|''p<sub>ψ</sub>''}} and solve for {{math|''dψ''/''dt''}} to find
:<math>\dot{\psi} = \frac{p_\psi}{I_3} - \cos\theta \left(\frac{p_\phi - p_\psi\cos\theta}{I_1\sin^2\theta}\right) \,.</math>
The Routhian can be taken to be
:<math>R(\theta,\dot{\theta}) = p_\psi\dot{\psi} + p_\phi\dot{\phi} - L = \frac{1}{2}(p_\psi\dot{\psi} + p_\phi\dot{\phi}) - \frac{I_1 \dot{\theta}^2}{2} + Mg\ell \cos\theta </math>
and since
:<math> \frac{p_\phi\dot{\phi}}{2} = \frac{p_\phi^2}{2I_1\sin^2\theta} - \frac{p_\psi p_\phi\cos\theta}{2I_1\sin^2\theta}\,, </math>
:<math>\frac{p_\psi \dot{\psi}}{2} = \frac{p_\psi^2}{2I_3} - \frac{p_\psi p_\phi\cos\theta }{2I_1\sin^2\theta} + \frac{p_\psi^2 \cos^2\theta}{2I_1\sin^2\theta}</math>
we have
:<math>R = \frac{p_\psi^2}{2I_3} + \frac{p_\psi^2 \cos^2\theta}{2I_1\sin^2\theta} + \frac{p_\phi^2}{2I_1\sin^2\theta} - \frac{p_\psi p_\phi\cos\theta}{4I_1\sin^2\theta} - \frac{I_1 \dot{\theta}^2}{2} + Mg\ell \cos\theta \,. </math>
The first term is constant, and can be ignored since only the derivatives of ''R'' will enter the equations of motion. The simplified Routhian, without loss of information, is thus
:<math>R = \frac{1}{2I_1\sin^2\theta}\left[p_\psi^2 \cos^2\theta + p_\phi^2 - \frac{p_\psi p_\phi}{2} \cos\theta\right] - \frac{I_1 \dot{\theta}^2}{2} + Mg\ell \cos\theta </math>
The equation of motion for {{math|''θ''}} is, by direct calculation,
:<math>\frac{d}{dt}\frac{\partial R}{\partial \dot{\theta}} = \frac{\partial R}{\partial \theta} \quad \Rightarrow \quad </math>
:<math>-I_1\ddot{\theta} = -\frac{\cos\theta}{I_1\sin^3\theta}\left[p_\psi^2 \cos^2\theta + p_\phi^2 - \frac{p_\psi p_\phi}{2} \cos\theta\right] + \frac{1}{2I_1\sin^2\theta} \left[-2 p_\psi^2 \cos\theta\sin\theta + \frac{p_\psi p_\phi}{2} \sin\theta\right] -Mg\ell\sin\theta \,, </math>
or by introducing the constants
:<math>a = \frac{p_\psi^2}{I_1^2} \,,\quad b = \frac{p_\phi^2}{I_1^2}\,,\quad c=\frac{p_\psi p_\phi}{2 I_1^2}\,,\quad k= \frac{Mg\ell}{I_1}\,,</math>
a simpler form of the equation is obtained
:<math>\ddot{\theta} = \frac{\cos\theta}{\sin^3\theta}( a\cos^2\theta +b -c\cos\theta ) + \frac{1}{2\sin\theta} (2 a \cos\theta - c) + k\sin\theta \,. </math>
Although the equation is highly nonlinear, there is only one equation to solve for, it was obtained directly, and the cyclic coordinates are not involved.
By contrast, the Lagrangian approach leads to ''three'' nonlinear coupled equations to solve, despite the absence of the coordinates {{math|''ψ''}} and {{math|''φ''}} in the Lagrangian.
The {{math|''θ''}} equation is
:<math>\frac{d}{dt}\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{\theta}} = \frac{\partial L}{\partial \theta} \quad\Rightarrow \quad I_1\ddot{\theta} = (I_1- I_3)\dot{\phi}^2\sin\theta\cos\theta -I_3\dot{\psi}\dot{\phi}\sin\theta +Mg\ell\sin\theta\,,</math>
the {{math|''ψ''}} equation is
:<math>\frac{d}{dt}\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{\psi}} = \frac{\partial L}{\partial \psi} \quad\Rightarrow \quad \ddot{\psi} + \ddot{\phi}\cos\theta - \dot{\phi}\dot{\theta}\sin\theta= 0 \,,</math>
and the {{math|''φ''}} equation is
:<math>\frac{d}{dt}\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{\phi}} = \frac{\partial L}{\partial \phi} \quad\Rightarrow \quad \ddot{\phi}(I_1\sin^2\theta + I_3\cos^2\theta) + \dot{\phi}(I_1 - I_3)2\sin\theta\cos\theta\dot{\theta} + I_3\ddot{\psi}\cos\theta - I_3\dot{\psi}\sin\theta\dot{\theta} =0 \,,</math>
=== Velocity-dependent potentials ===
==== Classical charged particle in a uniform magnetic field ==== [[File:Charged particle in uniform B field.svg|thumb|300px|Classical charged particle in uniform '''B''' field, using cylindrical coordinates. '''Top:''' If the radial coordinate {{math|''r''}} and angular velocity {{math|''dθ''/''dt''}} vary, the trajectory is a helicoid with varying radius but uniform motion in the {{math|''z''}} direction. '''Bottom:''' Constant {{math|''r''}} and {{math|''dθ''/''dt''}} means a helicoid with constant radius.]]
Consider a classical [[charged particle]] of mass {{math|''m''}} and [[electric charge]] {{math|''q''}} in a static (time-independent) uniform (constant throughout space) [[magnetic field]] {{math|'''B'''}}.<ref>{{harvnb|Kibble|Berkshire|2004|page=243}}</ref> The Lagrangian for a charged particle in a general [[electromagnetic field]] given by the [[magnetic potential]] {{math|'''A'''}} and [[electric potential]] {{math|''φ''}} is
:<math>L = \frac{m}{2} \dot{\mathbf{r}}^2 - q \phi + q \dot{\mathbf{r}} \cdot \mathbf{A} \,, </math>
It is convenient to use [[cylindrical coordinates]] {{math|(''r'', ''θ'', ''z'')}}, so that
:<math>\dot{\mathbf{r}} = \mathbf{v} = (v_r, v_\theta,v_z) = (\dot{r},r\dot{\theta},\dot{z}) \,, </math> :<math>\mathbf{B} = (B_r,B_\theta,B_z) = (0,0,B)\,. </math>
In this case the electric potential is zero, {{math|''φ'' {{=}} 0}}, and we can choose the axial gauge for the magnetic potential
:<math>\mathbf{A} = \frac{1}{2}\mathbf{B}\times\mathbf{r} \quad \Rightarrow \quad \mathbf{A} = (A_r,A_\theta,A_z) = (0,Br/2,0)\,, </math>
and the Lagrangian is
:<math>L(r,\dot{r},\dot{\theta},\dot{z}) = \frac{m}{2} (\dot{r}^2 + r^2\dot{\theta}^2 + \dot{z}^2) + \frac{qB r^2\dot{\theta}}{2} \,. </math>
Notice this potential has an effectively cylindrical symmetry (although it also has angular velocity dependence), since the only spatial dependence is on the radial length from an imaginary cylinder axis.
There are two cyclic coordinates, {{math|''θ''}} and {{math|''z''}}. The canonical momenta conjugate to {{math|''θ''}} and {{math|''z''}} are the constants
:<math>p_{\theta} = \frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot {\theta}} = mr^2\dot {\theta} + \frac{qBr^2}{2} \,,\quad p_z = \frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot {z}} = m\dot{z} \,,</math>
so the velocities are
:<math>\dot {\theta} = \frac{1}{mr^2}\left(p_\theta - \frac{qBr^2}{2}\right) \,,\quad \dot{z} = \frac{p_z}{m}\,.</math>
The angular momentum about the ''z'' axis is ''not'' {{math|''p<sub>θ</sub>''}}, but the quantity {{math|''mr''<sup>2</sup>''dθ''/''dt''}}, which is not conserved due to the contribution from the magnetic field. The canonical momentum {{math|''p<sub>θ</sub>''}} is the conserved quantity. It is still the case that {{math|''p<sub>z</sub>''}} is the linear or translational momentum along the ''z'' axis, which is also conserved.
The radial component {{math|''r''}} and angular velocity {{math|''dθ''/''dt''}} can vary with time, but {{math|''p<sub>θ</sub>''}} is constant, and since {{math|''p<sub>z</sub>''}} is constant it follows {{math|''dz''/''dt''}} is constant. The Routhian can take the form
:<math>\begin{align} R(r,\dot{r}) & = p_{\theta}\dot{\theta}+p_z\dot{z} - L \\ & = p_{\theta}\dot{\theta}+p_z\dot{z} - \frac{m}{2}\dot r^2 - \frac{p_\theta\dot{\theta}}{2} - \frac{p_z\dot{z}}{2} - \frac{1}{2}qBr^2\dot{\theta} \\ & = (p_\theta - qBr^2 )\frac{\dot{\theta}}{2} - \frac{m}{2}\dot r^2 + \frac{p_z\dot{z}}{2} \\ & = \frac{1}{2mr^2} \left(p_\theta - qBr^2 \right)\left(p_\theta - \frac{qBr^2}{2} \right) - \frac{m}{2}\dot{r}^2 + \frac{p_z^2}{2m} \\ & = \frac{1}{2mr^2} \left(p_\theta^2 - \frac{3}{2}qBr^2 + \frac{(qB)^2r^4}{2} \right) - \frac{m}{2}\dot{r}^2 \end{align}</math>
where in the last line, the {{math|''p<sub>z</sub><sup>2</sup>''/2''m''}} term is a constant and can be ignored without loss of continuity. The Hamiltonian equations for {{math|''θ''}} and {{math|''z''}} automatically vanish and do not need to be solved for. The Lagrangian equation in {{math|''r''}}
:<math>\frac{d}{dt}\frac{\partial R}{\partial \dot{r}} = \frac{\partial R}{\partial r} </math>
is by direct calculation
:<math>-m\ddot{r} = \frac{1}{2m}\left[\frac{-2}{r^3} \left(p_\theta^2 - \frac{3}{2}qBr^2 + \frac{(qB)^2 r^4}{2} \right) + \frac{1}{r^2}(- 3qBr + 2(qB)^2r^3)\right] \,, </math>
which after collecting terms is
:<math>m\ddot{r}=\frac{1}{2m}\left[\frac{2p_{\theta}^2}{r^3}-(qB)^2 r\right] \,, </math>
and simplifying further by introducing the constants
:<math>a = \frac{p_{\theta}^2}{m^2} \,,\quad b = - \frac{(qB)^2}{2m^2} \,, </math>
the differential equation is
:<math>\ddot{r} = \frac{a}{r^3} + br </math>
To see how {{math|''z''}} changes with time, integrate the momenta expression for {{math|''p<sub>z</sub>''}} above
:<math> z = \frac{p_z}{m}t + c_z \,,</math>
where {{math|''c<sub>z</sub>''}} is an arbitrary constant, the initial value of {{math|''z''}} to be specified in the [[initial conditions]].
The motion of the particle in this system is [[helicoid]]al, with the axial motion uniform (constant) but the radial and angular components varying in a spiral according to the equation of motion derived above. The initial conditions on {{math|''r''}}, {{math|''dr''/''dt''}}, {{math|''θ''}}, {{math|''dθ''/''dt''}}, will determine if the trajectory of the particle has a constant {{math|''r''}} or varying {{math|''r''}}. If initially {{math|''r''}} is nonzero but {{math|''dr''/''dt'' {{=}} 0}}, while {{math|''θ''}} and {{math|''dθ''/''dt''}} are arbitrary, then the initial velocity of the particle has no radial component, {{math|''r''}} is constant, so the motion will be in a perfect helix. If ''r'' is constant, the angular velocity is also constant according to the conserved {{math|''p<sub>θ</sub>''}}.
With the Lagrangian approach, the equation for {{math|''r''}} would include {{math|''dθ''/''dt''}} which has to be eliminated, and there would be equations for {{math|''θ''}} and {{math|''z''}} to solve for.
The {{math|''r''}} equation is
:<math>\frac{d}{dt} \frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{r}} = \frac{\partial L}{\partial r} \quad\Rightarrow\quad m\ddot{r} = mr\dot{\theta}^2 + qBr\dot{\theta} \,,</math>
the {{math|''θ''}} equation is
:<math>\frac{d}{dt} \frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{\theta}} = \frac{\partial L}{\partial \theta} \quad\Rightarrow\quad m(2r\dot{r}\dot {\theta} + r^2\ddot {\theta}) + qBr\dot{r} = 0 \,,</math>
and the {{math|''z''}} equation is
:<math>\frac{d}{dt} \frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{z}} = \frac{\partial L}{\partial z} \quad\Rightarrow\quad m\ddot{z} = 0 \,.</math>
The {{math|''z''}} equation is trivial to integrate, but the {{math|''r''}} and {{math|''θ''}} equations are not, in any case the time derivatives are mixed in all the equations and must be eliminated.

{{Infobox software | name = Sketch Engine | title = | logo = Sketch Engine logo.svg | logo caption = Logo of Sketch Engine | logo size = 250px | logo alt = | screenshot = Concordance_in_Sketch_Engine.png | caption = Sketch Engine concordance page | screenshot size = | screenshot alt = | collapsible = | author = [[Adam Kilgarriff]], Pavel Rychlý | developer = Lexical Computing Ltd. | released = {{Start date and age|2003|07|23|df=yes}}<ref>[http://wck2.companieshouse.gov.uk/ Companies House] Searched on [[United Kingdom]]'s [[registrar of companies]] (Company name: LEXICAL COMPUTING LIMITED or Company number: 04841901)</ref> | discontinued = | latest release version = | latest release date = <!-- {{Start date and age|YYYY|MM|DD|df=yes/no}} --> | latest preview version = | latest preview date = <!-- {{Start date and age|YYYY|MM|DD|df=yes/no}} --> | status = Active | programming language = [[C++]], [[Python (programming language)|Python]], [[JavaScript]], [[jQuery]] | operating system = [[Linux]], [[Mac OS X]] | platform = [[IA-32]], [[x64]] or [[IA-64]] | size = | language = English, Czech, Chinese (Traditional, Simplified), Gaeilge, Slovene, Croatian, Arabic, Spanish, French, Ukrainian, Polish | language count = 12 | language footnote = | genre = [[Corpus manager]] for 90+ languages, [[database management systems|database management system]] | license = [[Proprietary software]]; both [[commercial software|commercial]] and [[freeware]] editions are available | alexa = | website = {{URL|www.sketchengine.co.uk}} | standard = [[Unicode]] | AsOf = }}
'''Sketch Engine''' is a corpus manager and [[text analysis]] software developed by Lexical Computing Limited since 2003. Its purpose is to enable people studying language behaviour ([[lexicographers]], researchers in [[corpus linguistics]], translators or language learners) to search large text collections according to complex and linguistically motivated queries. Sketch Engine gained its name after one of the key features, [[word sketch]]es: one-page, automatic, corpus-derived summaries of a word's grammatical and collocational behaviour.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Kilgarriff|first1=Adam|last2=Baisa|first2=Vít|last3=Bušta|first3=Jan|last4=Jakubíček|first4=Miloš|last5=Kovář|first5=Vojtěch|last6=Michelfeit|first6=Jan|last7=Rychlý|first7=Pavel|last8=Suchomel|first8=Vít|title=The Sketch Engine: ten years on|journal=Lexicography|date=10 July 2014|volume=1|issue=1|pages=7–36|doi=10.1007/s40607-014-0009-9|issn=2197-4292|url=https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s40607-014-0009-9|publisher=Springer Berlin Heidelberg}}</ref> Currently, it supports and provides corpora in 90+ languages.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.sketchengine.co.uk/user-guide/user-manual/corpora/by-language/ |title= Languages in Sketch Engine |author=<!--Not stated--> |date= |website=Sketch Engine |publisher=Lexical Computing s.r.o. |access-date=22 January 2018}}</ref>
== History of development == Sketch Engine is a product of Lexical Computing Limited, a company founded in 2003 by the lexicographer and research scientist [[Adam Kilgarriff]].<ref>[http://kilgarriff.co.uk Adam Kilgarriff's home page]</ref> He started collaboration with Pavel Rychlý, a computer scientist working at the Natural Language Processing Centre at [[Masaryk University]]<ref>[http://nlp.fi.muni.cz Natural Language Processing Centre, Masaryk University]</ref> and the developer of Manatee and Bonito (two major parts of the software suite), and introduced the concept of [[word sketch]]es.
Since then, Sketch Engine has been commercial software, however all the core features of Manatee and Bonito that were developed by 2003 (and extended since then) are freely available under the [[GPL]] license within the NoSketch Engine suite.<ref>[http://nlp.fi.muni.cz/trac/noske NoSketch Engine]</ref>
== Features == * [[Word sketch]]es – a one-page automatic derived summary of a word’s grammatical and collocational behaviour * Word sketch difference – compares and contrasts two words by analysing their collocation * Distributional [[Thesaurus]] – automated thesaurus finding words with similar meaning or appearing in the same/similar context * [[Concordance (publishing)|Concordance]] search – finds examples of a word form, lemma, phrase, tag or complex structure * [[Collocation]] search – word co-occurrence analysis displaying the most frequent words (to a search word) which can be regarded as collocation candidates * Word lists – generates frequency lists which can be filtered with complex criteria * [[n-gram]]s – generates frequency lists of multi-word expressions * [[Terminology extraction|Terminology]] / [[Keyword (linguistics)|Keyword]] extraction (both monolingual and bilingual) – automatic extraction key words and multi-word terms from texts (based on frequency count and linguistic criteria) * Diachronic analysis ([[Trend analysis|Trends]])<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Kilgarriff|first1=Adam|last2=Herman|first2=Ondřej|last3=Bušta|first3=Jan|last4=Rychlý|first4=Pavel|last5=Jakubíček|first5=Miloš|title=DIACRAN: a framework for diachronic analysis|journal=Corpus Linguistics 2015|date=2015|pages=65–70|url=https://www.sketchengine.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/Diacran_CL2015.pdf|publisher=Lancaster: UCREL}}</ref> – detecting words which undergo changes in the frequency of use in time (show trending words) * Corpus building and management – create corpora from the Web or uploaded texts including [[part-of-speech tagging]] and [[lemmatization]] which can be used as [[data mining]] software * [[Parallel corpus]] (bilingual) facilities – looking up translation examples (EUR-Lex corpus, [[Europarl corpus]], OPUS corpus, etc.) or building parallel corpus from own aligned texts
== Architecture == [[File:Thesaurus in Sketch Engine.png|thumb|upright=1.5|alt=Sketch Engine thesaurus page|Thesaurus cloud of the lemma ''work'' in Sketch Engine]]
Sketch Engine consists of three main components: an underlying [[database management system]] called Manatee, a web interface search front-end called Bonito and a web interface for corpus building and management called Corpus Architect. <ref name="bonito">{{cite journal|last1=Rychlý|first1=Pavel|title=Manatee/bonito–a modular corpus manager|journal=1st Workshop on Recent Advances in Slavonic Natural Language Processing|date=2007|pages=65–70|url=http://nlp.fi.muni.cz/raslan/2007/raslan07.pdf#page=73|publisher=Masaryk University}}</ref>
=== Manatee ===
Manatee is a [[database management system]] specifically devised for effective indexing of large text corpora. It is based on the idea of [[inverted index]]ing (keeping an index of all positions of a given word in the text). It has been used to index text corpora comprising tens of billions of words.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Pomikálek|first1=Jan|last2=Jakubíček|first2=Miloš|last3=Rychlý|first3=Pavel|title=Building a 70 billion word corpus of English from ClueWeb|journal=Proceedings of the Eight International Conference on Language Resources and Evaluation (LREC'12)|date=2012|url=http://www.lrec-conf.org/proceedings/lrec2012/pdf/1047_Paper.pdf|publisher=European Language Resources Association (ELRA)|location=Istanbul, Turkey}}</ref>
Searching corpora indexed by Manatee is performed by formulating queries in the Corpus Query Language (CQL).<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.sketchengine.co.uk/documentation/corpus-querying/ |title=CQL – Corpus Query Language |author=<!--Not stated--> |date= |website=Sketch Engine |publisher=Lexical Computing s.r.o. |access-date=22 January 2018}}</ref>
Manatee is written in [[C++]] and offers an [[API]] for a number of other programming languages including [[Python (programming language)|Python]], [[Java (programming language)|Java]], [[Perl]] and [[Ruby (programming language)|Ruby]]. Recently, it was rewritten into [[Go (programming language)|Go]] for faster processing of corpus queries.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Rychlý|first1=Pavel|last2=Rábara|first2=Radoslav|title=Concurrent Processing of Text Corpus Queries|journal=Workshop on Recent Advances in Slavonic Natural Language Processing|date=2015|pages=49–58|url=https://www.sketchengine.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/Concurrent_Processing_2015.pdf|publisher=Masaryk University}}</ref>
=== Bonito ===
Bonito is a web interface for Manatee providing access to corpus search. In the [[client–server model]], Manatee is the server and Bonito plays the client part. It is written in [[Python (programming language)|Python]].<ref name="bonito" />
=== Corpus Architect ===
Corpus Architect is a web interface providing corpus building and management features. It is also written in [[Python (programming language)|Python]].
== Applications == Sketch Engine has been used by major British or other publishing houses for producing dictionaries such as [[Macmillan English Dictionary for Advanced Learners|Macmillan English Dictionary]], [[Dictionnaires Le Robert]], [[Oxford University Press]] or [[Shogakukan]] and four of the UK’s five biggest dictionary publishers use Sketch Engine.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://impact.ref.ac.uk/CaseStudies/CaseStudy.aspx?Id=39760 |title=Using Computational Lexicography for Dictionary Production with the Sketch Engine |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date= |website=REF Impact Case Studies |publisher=University of Brighton |access-date=18 April 2015}}</ref>
==See also== * [[SkELL]] – a free web service for students and teachers of English language based on Sketch Engine *[[TenTen Corpus Family]] – a multilingual set of comparable [[Web crawler|web corpora]] available through Sketch Engine
==References== {{Reflist}}
== Further reading == * {{Cite book|url=http://www.versatile.pub/deske.html|title=Discovering English with Sketch Engine : a corpus-based approach to language exploration. Workbook and glossary|last=Thomas|first=James|date=March 2016|publisher=Versatile|isbn=9788026095798|location=Brno|language=en}}
==External links== {{Commons category}} * [http://www.sketchengine.co.uk/ Sketch Engine website] * [http://www.sketchengine.co.uk/corpora/ List of corpora available in Sketch Engine]
[[Category:Applied linguistics]] [[Category:Corpus linguistics]] [[Category:Database management systems]] [[Category:Data mining and machine learning software]] [[Category:Lexicography]] [[Category:Linguistic research]] [[Category:Text analysis]] [[Category:Text mining]]

'''Sketch recognition''' is the automated recognition of hand-drawn [[diagram]]s by a [[computer]].<ref>Hammond, T. and Davis, R. (2005), [http://rationale.csail.mit.edu/publications/Hammond2005Ladder.pdf "LADDER, a sketching language for user interface developers"], Computers & Graphics, 2005, 29(4), pp. 518-532.</ref><ref>Hammond, T., Logsdon, D., Peschel, J., Johnston, J., Taele, P., Wolin, A., and Paulson, B. A sketch recognition interface that recognizes hundreds of shapes in course-of-action diagrams. In Proceedings of the 28th of the international conference extended abstracts on Human factors in computing systems (CHI EA '10), 2010, pp. 4213-4218. </ref><ref>Jorge, J. and Samavati, F. (2011), Sketch-Based Interfaces and Modeling, Springer</ref> Research in sketch recognition lies at the crossroads of [[Artificial intelligence|Artificial Intelligence]] and [[Human-computer interaction|Human Computer Interaction]]. Recognition algorithms usually are [[gesture]]-based, appearance-based, [[geometry]]-based, or a combination thereof.
==See also== * [[Gesture recognition]] * [[Handwriting recognition]] * [[Human–computer interaction]] * [[Multi-touch gestures]] * [[Pen computing]] * [[Tablet computer]] * [[Sketch-based modeling]]

revision.text:
In [[mathematics]], a '''t-norm''' (also '''T-norm''' or, unabbreviated, '''triangular norm''') is a kind of [[binary operation]] used in the framework of [[probabilistic metric space]]s and in [[multi-valued logic]], specifically in [[fuzzy logic]]. A t-norm generalizes [[intersection (set theory)|intersection]] in a [[lattice (order)|lattice]] and [[logical conjunction|conjunction]] in [[logic]]. The name ''triangular norm'' refers to the fact that in the framework of probabilistic metric spaces t-norms are used to generalize [[triangle inequality]] of ordinary [[metric space]]s.
== Definition ==
A t-norm is a [[function (mathematics)|function]] T: [0, 1] × [0, 1] → [0, 1] which satisfies the following properties: * [[Commutativity]]: T(''a'', ''b'') = T(''b'', ''a'') * [[Monotonicity]]: T(''a'', ''b'') ≤ T(''c'', ''d'') if ''a'' ≤ ''c'' and ''b'' ≤ ''d'' * [[Associativity]]: T(''a'', T(''b'', ''c'')) = T(T(''a'', ''b''), ''c'') * The number 1 acts as [[identity element]]: T(''a'', 1) = ''a''
Since a t-norm is a [[binary operation|binary algebraic operation]] on the interval [0, 1], infix algebraic notation is also common, with the t-norm usually denoted by <math>*</math>.
The defining conditions of the t-norm are exactly those of the partially ordered Abelian monoid on the real unit interval [0, 1]. '' (Cf. [[ordered group]].)'' The monoidal operation of any partially ordered Abelian monoid ''L'' is therefore by some authors called a ''triangular norm on L''.
=== Motivations and applications ===
T-norms are a generalization of the usual two-valued [[logical conjunction]], studied by classical logic, for [[fuzzy logic]]s. Indeed, the classical Boolean conjunction is both commutative and associative. The monotonicity property ensures that the [[degree of truth]] of conjunction does not decrease if the [[truth value]]s of conjuncts increase. The requirement that 1 be an identity element corresponds to the interpretation of 1 as ''true'' (and consequently 0 as ''false''). Continuity, which is often required from fuzzy conjunction as well, expresses the idea that, roughly speaking, very small changes in truth values of conjuncts should not macroscopically affect the truth value of their conjunction.
T-norms are also used to construct the [[intersection (set theory)|intersection]] of [[fuzzy set]]s or as a basis for aggregation operators (see [[fuzzy set operations]]). In [[probabilistic metric space]]s, t-norms are used to generalize [[triangle inequality]] of ordinary metric spaces. Individual t-norms may of course frequently occur in further disciplines of mathematics, since the class contains many familiar functions.
=== Classification of t-norms ===
A t-norm is called ''continuous'' if it is [[continuous function|continuous]] as a function, in the usual interval topology on [0, 1]<sup>2</sup>. (Similarly for ''left-'' and ''right-continuity''.)
A t-norm is called ''strict'' if it is continuous and [[monotonic function|strictly monotone]].
A t-norm is called ''nilpotent'' if it is continuous and each ''x'' in the open interval (0, 1) is its [[nilpotent]] element, i.e., there is a natural number ''n'' such that ''x'' <math>*</math> ... <math>*</math> ''x'' (''n'' times) equals 0.
A t-norm <math>*</math> is called ''Archimedean'' if it has the [[Archimedean property]], i.e., if for each ''x'', ''y'' in the open interval (0, 1) there is a natural number ''n'' such that ''x'' <math>*</math> ... <math>*</math> ''x'' (''n'' times) is less than or equal to ''y''.
The usual partial ordering of t-norms is pointwise, i.e., : T<sub>1</sub> ≤ T<sub>2</sub>   if   T<sub>1</sub>(''a'', ''b'') ≤ T<sub>2</sub>(''a'', ''b'') for all ''a'', ''b'' in [0, 1]. As functions, pointwise larger t-norms are sometimes called ''stronger'' than those pointwise smaller. In the semantics of fuzzy logic, however, the larger a t-norm, the ''weaker'' (in terms of logical strength) conjunction it represents.
{{Anchor|Minimum t-norm|Product t-norm|Lukasiewicz t-norm|Drastic t-norm|Nilpotent-minimum t-norm|Hamacher-product t-norm}}
==Prominent examples==
[[File:MinimumTnorm-graph-contour.png|thumb|270px|Graph of the minimum t-norm (3D and contours)]] *'''Minimum t-norm''' <math>\top_{\mathrm{min}}(a, b) = \min \{a, b\},</math> also called the '''Gödel t-norm''', as it is the standard semantics for conjunction in [[Gödel fuzzy logic]]. Besides that, it occurs in most t-norm based fuzzy logics as the standard semantics for weak conjunction. It is the pointwise largest t-norm (see the [[#Properties of t-norms|properties of t-norms]] below).
[[File:ProductTnorm-graph-contour.png|thumb|270px|Graph of the product t-norm]] *'''Product t-norm''' <math>\top_{\mathrm{prod}}(a, b) = a \cdot b</math> (the ordinary product of real numbers). Besides other uses, the product t-norm is the standard semantics for strong conjunction in [[product fuzzy logic]]. It is a strict Archimedean t-norm.
[[File:LukasiewiczTnorm-graph-contour.png|thumb|270px|Graph of the Łukasiewicz t-norm]] *'''Łukasiewicz t-norm''' <math>\top_{\mathrm{Luk}}(a, b) = \max \{0, a+b-1\}.</math> The name comes from the fact that the t-norm is the standard semantics for strong conjunction in [[Łukasiewicz fuzzy logic]]. It is a nilpotent Archimedean t-norm, pointwise smaller than the product t-norm.
[[File:DrasticTnorm-graph-contour.png|thumb|270px|Graph of the drastic t-norm. The function is discontinuous at the lines 0 < ''x'' = 1 and 0 < ''y'' = 1.]] *'''Drastic t-norm''' ::<math>\top_{\mathrm{D}}(a, b) = \begin{cases} b & \mbox{if }a=1 \\ a & \mbox{if }b=1 \\ 0 & \mbox{otherwise.} \end{cases}</math> :The name reflects the fact that the drastic t-norm is the pointwise smallest t-norm (see the [[#Properties of t-norms|properties of t-norms]] below). It is a right-continuous Archimedean t-norm.
[[File:NilpotentMinimum-graph-contour.png|thumb|270px|Graph of the nilpotent minimum. The function is discontinuous at the line 0 < ''x'' = 1 − ''y'' < 1.]] *'''Nilpotent minimum''' ::<math>\top_{\mathrm{nM}}(a, b) = \begin{cases} \min(a,b) & \mbox{if }a+b > 1 \\ 0 & \mbox{otherwise} \end{cases}</math> :is a standard example of a t-norm which is left-continuous, but not continuous. Despite its name, the nilpotent minimum is not a nilpotent t-norm.
[[File:HamacherProduct-graph-contour.png|thumb|270px|Graph of the Hamacher product]] *'''Hamacher product''' ::<math>\top_{\mathrm{H}_0}(a, b) = \begin{cases} 0 & \mbox{if } a=b=0 \\ \frac{ab}{a+b-ab} & \mbox{otherwise} \end{cases}</math> :is a strict Archimedean t-norm, and an important representative of the parametric classes of [[Construction of t-norms#Hamacher t-norms|Hamacher t-norms]] and [[Construction of t-norms#Schweizer–Sklar t-norms|Schweizer–Sklar t-norms]].
==Properties of t-norms==
The drastic t-norm is the pointwise smallest t-norm and the minimum is the pointwise largest t-norm: :<math>\top_{\mathrm{D}}(a, b) \le \top(a, b) \le \mathrm{\top_{min}}(a, b),</math> for any t-norm <math>\top</math> and all ''a'', ''b'' in [0, 1].
For every t-norm T, the number 0 acts as null element: T(''a'', 0) = 0 for all ''a'' in [0, 1].
A t-norm T has [[zero divisor]]s if and only if it has [[nilpotent element|nilpotent]] elements; each nilpotent element of T is also a zero divisor of T. The set of all nilpotent elements is an interval [0, ''a''] or [0, ''a''), for some ''a'' in [0, 1].
=== Properties of continuous t-norms ===
Although real functions of two variables can be continuous in each variable without being continuous on [0, 1]<sup>2</sup>, this is not the case with t-norms: a t-norm T is continuous if and only if it is continuous in one variable, i.e., if and only if the functions ''f<sub>y</sub>''(''x'') = T(''x'', ''y'') are continuous for each ''y'' in [0, 1]. Analogous theorems hold for left- and right-continuity of a t-norm.
A continuous t-norm is Archimedean if and only if 0 and 1 are its only [[idempotent]]s.
A continuous Archimedean t-norm is strict if 0 is its only [[nilpotent]] element; otherwise it is nilpotent. By definition, moreover, a continuous Archimedean t-norm T is nilpotent if and only if ''each'' ''x'' < 1 is a nilpotent element of T. Thus with a continuous Archimedean t-norm T, either all or none of the elements of (0, 1) are nilpotent. If it is the case that all elements in (0, 1) are nilpotent, then the t-norm is isomorphic to the Łukasiewicz t-norm; i.e., there is a strictly increasing function ''f'' such that :<math>\top(x,y) = f^{-1}(\top_{\mathrm{Luk}}(f(x), f(y))).</math> If on the other hand it is the case that there are no nilpotent elements of T, the t-norm is isomorphic to the product t-norm. In other words, all nilpotent t-norms are isomorphic, the Łukasiewicz t-norm being their prototypical representative; and all strict t-norms are isomorphic, with the product t-norm as their prototypical example. The Łukasiewicz t-norm is itself isomorphic to the product t-norm undercut at 0.25, i.e., to the function ''p''(''x'', ''y'') = max(0.25, ''x'' · ''y'') on [0.25, 1]<sup>2</sup>.
For each continuous t-norm, the set of its idempotents is a closed subset of [0, 1]. Its complement — the set of all elements which are not idempotent — is therefore a union of countably many non-overlapping open intervals. The restriction of the t-norm to any of these intervals (including its endpoints) is Archimedean, and thus isomorphic either to the Łukasiewicz t-norm or the product t-norm. For such ''x'', ''y'' that do not fall into the same open interval of non-idempotents, the t-norm evaluates to the minimum of ''x'' and ''y''. These conditions actually give a characterization of continuous t-norms, called the '''Mostert–Shields theorem''', since every continuous t-norm can in this way be decomposed, and the described construction always yields a continuous t-norm. The theorem can also be formulated as follows: :A t-norm is continuous if and only if it is isomorphic to an [[Construction of t-norms#Ordinal sums|ordinal sum]] of the minimum, Łukasiewicz, and product t-norm.
A similar characterization theorem for non-continuous t-norms is not known (not even for left-continuous ones), only some non-exhaustive methods for the [[construction of t-norms]] have been found.
== Residuum ==
For any left-continuous t-norm <math>\top</math>, there is a unique binary operation <math>\Rightarrow</math> on [0, 1] such that :<math>\top(z, x) \le y</math> if and only if <math>z \le (x \Rightarrow y)</math> for all ''x'', ''y'', ''z'' in [0, 1]. This operation is called the ''residuum'' of the t-norm. In prefix notation, the residuum to a t-norm <math>\top</math> is often denoted by <math>\vec{\top}</math> or by the letter R.
The interval [0, 1] equipped with a t-norm and its residuum forms a [[residuated lattice]]. The relation between a t-norm T and its residuum R is an instance of [[adjoint functors#Posets|adjunction]] (specifically, a [[Galois connection]]): the residuum forms a right adjoint R(''x'', –) to the functor T(–, ''x'') for each ''x'' in the lattice [0, 1] taken as a [[poset]] category.
In the standard semantics of t-norm based fuzzy logics, where conjunction is interpreted by a t-norm, the residuum plays the role of implication (often called ''R-implication'').
=== Basic properties of residua ===
If <math>\Rightarrow</math> is the residuum of a left-continuous t-norm <math>\top</math>, then :<math>(x \Rightarrow y) = \sup\{z\mid\top(z,x) \le y\}.</math> Consequently, for all ''x'', ''y'' in the unit interval, :<math>(x \Rightarrow y) = 1</math> if and only if <math>x \le y</math> and :<math>(1 \Rightarrow y) = y.</math>
If <math>*</math> is a left-continuous t-norm and <math>\Rightarrow</math> its residuum, then :<math>\begin{array}{rcl} \min(x,y) & \ge & x * (x \Rightarrow y) \\ \max(x, y) & = & \min((x \Rightarrow y)\Rightarrow y, (y \Rightarrow x)\Rightarrow x). \end{array}</math> If <math>*</math> is continuous, then equality holds in the former.
=== Residua of prominent left-continuous t-norms ===
If ''x'' ≤ ''y'', then R(''x'', ''y'') = 1 for any residuum R. The following table therefore gives the values of prominent residua only for ''x'' > ''y''.
{| class="wikitable" ! Residuum of the !! Name !! Value for ''x'' > ''y'' !! Graph |- | Minimum t-norm | Standard Gōdel implication | align="center" | ''y'' | [[File:ResiduumMinimumTnorm-graph-contour.png|thumb|270px|left|Standard Gödel implication. The function is discontinuous at the line ''y'' = ''x'' < 1.]] |- | Product t-norm | [[Joseph Goguen|Goguen]] implication | align="center" | ''y'' / ''x'' | [[File:ResiduumProductTnorm-graph-contour.png|thumb|270px|left|Goguen implication. The function is discontinuous at the point ''x'' = ''y'' = 0.]] |- | Łukasiewicz t-norm | Standard Łukasiewicz implication | align="center" | 1 – ''x'' + ''y'' | [[File:ResiduumLukasiewiczTnorm-graph-contour.png|thumb|270px|left|Standard Łukasiewicz implication.]] |- | Nilpotent minimum | | align="center" | max(1 – ''x'', ''y'') | [[File:ResiduumNilpotentMinimum-graph-contour.png|thumb|270px|left|Residuum of the nilpotent minimum. The function is discontinuous at the line 0 < ''y'' = ''x'' < 1.]] |}
== T-conorms ==
'''T-conorms''' (also called '''S-norms''') are dual to t-norms under the order-reversing operation which assigns 1 – ''x'' to ''x'' on [0, 1]. Given a t-norm <math>\top</math>, the complementary conorm is defined by : <math>\bot(a,b) = 1-\top(1-a, 1-b).</math> This generalizes [[De Morgan's laws]].
It follows that a t-conorm satisfies the following conditions, which can be used for an equivalent axiomatic definition of t-conorms independently of t-norms: * Commutativity: ⊥(''a'', ''b'') = ⊥(''b'', ''a'') * Monotonicity: ⊥(''a'', ''b'') ≤ ⊥(''c'', ''d'') if ''a'' ≤ ''c'' and ''b'' ≤ ''d'' * Associativity: ⊥(''a'', ⊥(''b'', ''c'')) = ⊥(⊥(''a'', ''b''), ''c'') * Identity element: ⊥(''a'', 0) = ''a''
T-conorms are used to represent [[logical disjunction]] in [[fuzzy logic]] and [[union (set theory)|union]] in [[fuzzy set theory]].
===Examples of t-conorms===
Important t-conorms are those dual to prominent t-norms:
[[File:MaximumTconorm-graph-contour.png|thumb|270px|Graph of the maximum t-conorm (3D and contours)]] *'''Maximum t-conorm''' <math>\bot_{\mathrm{max}}(a, b) = \max \{a, b\}</math>, dual to the minimum t-norm, is the smallest t-conorm (see the [[#Properties of t-conorms|properties of t-conorms]] below). It is the standard semantics for disjunction in [[Gödel fuzzy logic]] and for weak disjunction in all t-norm based fuzzy logics.
[[File:ProbabilisticSum-graph-contour.png|thumb|270px|Graph of the probabilistic sum]] *'''Probabilistic sum''' <math>\bot_{\mathrm{sum}}(a, b) = a + b - a \cdot b</math> is dual to the product t-norm. In [[probability theory]] it expresses the probability of the union of independent [[event (probability theory)|event]]s. It is also the standard semantics for strong disjunction in such extensions of [[product fuzzy logic]] in which it is definable (e.g., those containing involutive negation).
[[File:BoundedSum-graph-contour.png|thumb|270px|Graph of the bounded sum t-conorm]] *'''Bounded sum''' <math>\bot_{\mathrm{Luk}}(a, b) = \min \{a+b, 1\}</math> is dual to the Łukasiewicz t-norm. It is the standard semantics for strong disjunction in [[Łukasiewicz fuzzy logic]].
[[File:DrasticTconorm-graph-contour.png|thumb|270px|Graph of the drastic t-conorm. The function is discontinuous at the lines 1 > ''x'' = 0 and 1 > ''y'' = 0.]] *'''Drastic t-conorm''' ::<math>\bot_{\mathrm{D}}(a, b) = \begin{cases} b & \mbox{if }a=0 \\ a & \mbox{if }b=0 \\ 1 & \mbox{otherwise,} \end{cases}</math> :dual to the drastic t-norm, is the largest t-conorm (see the [[#Properties of t-conorms|properties of t-conorms]] below).
[[File:NilpotentMaximum-graph-contour.png|thumb|270px|Graph of the nilpotent maximum. The function is discontinuous at the line 0 < ''x'' = 1 – ''y'' < 1.]] *'''Nilpotent maximum''', dual to the nilpotent minimum: ::<math>\bot_{\mathrm{nM}}(a, b) = \begin{cases} \max(a,b) & \mbox{if }a+b < 1 \\ 1 & \mbox{otherwise.} \end{cases}</math>
[[File:EinsteinSum-graph-contour.png|thumb|270px|Graph of the Einstein sum]] *'''Einstein sum''' (compare the [[velocity-addition formula]] under special relativity) ::<math>\bot_{\mathrm{H}_2}(a, b) = \frac{a+b}{1+ab}</math> :is a dual to one of the [[Construction of t-norms#Hamacher t-norms|Hamacher t-norms]].
===Properties of t-conorms===
Many properties of t-conorms can be obtained by dualizing the properties of t-norms, for example: * For any t-conorm ⊥, the number 1 is an annihilating element: ⊥(''a'', 1) = 1, for any ''a'' in [0, 1]. * Dually to t-norms, all t-conorms are bounded by the maximum and the drastic t-conorm: ::<math>\mathrm{\bot_{max}}(a, b) \le \bot(a, b) \le \bot_{\mathrm{D}}(a, b)</math>, for any t-conorm <math>\bot</math> and all ''a'', ''b'' in [0, 1].
Further properties result from the relationships between t-norms and t-conorms or their interplay with other operators, e.g.: * A t-norm T [[distributivity|distributes]] over a t-conorm ⊥, i.e., ::T(''x'', ⊥(''y'', ''z'')) = ⊥(T(''x'', ''y''), T(''x'', ''z'')) for all ''x'', ''y'', ''z'' in [0, 1], :if and only if ⊥ is the maximum t-conorm. Dually, any t-conorm distributes over the minimum, but not over any other t-norm.
===Non-standard negators===
A '''negator''' <math>n:[0,1] \to [0,1]</math> is a [[Monotonic function#Monotonicity in functional analysis|monotonous]] falling, i. e. order-reversion mapping with <math>n(0) = 1</math> and <math>n(1) = 0</math> (in other notation: <math>0 \mapsto 1</math> and <math>1 \mapsto 0</math>). A negator n is called * '''strict''' in case of strict monotonocity * '''strong''' if it is strict and involutive (see: [[Involution (mathematics)|involution]]): [[Universal quantification#notation|<math>\forall</math>]] <math>x \in [0,1]: n(n(x)) = x</math>. The standard (canonical) negator is <math>n(x) = 1 - x, x \in [0, 1]</math>, which appears to be strong. As the standard negator is used in the above definition of a t-norm/t-conorm pair, this can be generalized as follows:
A '''De Morgan Triplet''' is a triple (T,⊥,n) [[iff]] (if and only if) # T is a t-norm # ⊥ is a t-conorm according to the axiomatic definition of t-conorms as mentioned above # n is a strong negator # <math>\forall a,b \in [0, 1]: \,n(\perp(a, b)) = T(n(a), n(b))</math>. <ref>Ismat Beg, Samina Ashraf: [https://www.researchgate.net/publication/228744370_Similarity_measures_for_fuzzy_sets Similarity measures for fuzzy sets], at: Applied and Computational Mathematics, March 2009, available on Research Gate since November 23rd, 2016</ref>

Dordrecht: Kluwer. {{isbn|0-7923-5238-6}} * Cignoli, Roberto L.O.; D'Ottaviano, Itala M.L.; and Mundici, Daniele (2000), ''Algebraic Foundations of Many-valued Reasoning''. Dordrecht: Kluwer. {{isbn|0-7923-6009-5}} * Fodor, János (2004), [http://www.bmf.hu/journal/Fodor_2.pdf "Left-continuous t-norms in fuzzy logic: An overview".] ''Acta Polytechnica Hungarica'' '''1'''(2), {{issn|1785-8860}} [http://www.bmf.hu/journal/]

'''The Herbert Medal''' is awarded by the [[International Bulb Society]] to those whose achievements in advancing knowledge of [[ornamental bulbous plant]]s is considered to be outstanding.[http://www.bulbsociety.org/ABOUT_IBS/Awards/HERBERT_MEDAL/index.html International Bulb Society] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060825104052/http://www.bulbsociety.org/ABOUT_IBS/Awards/HERBERT_MEDAL/index.html |date=August 25, 2006 }} The medal is named for [[William Herbert, Dean of Manchester|William Herbert]], a noted 19th-century [[botanist]]. He published many articles in the ''[[Botanical Register]]'' and the ''[[Botanical Magazine]]'' on the subject of bulbous plants, many of which he cultivated in his own gardens. He wrote what became the standard work on the family ''[[Amaryllidaceae]]'' in 1837. He also published extensively on hybridization based on his own experiments,{{cite DNB|wstitle=Herbert, William (1778-1847)}} not only on bulbs but also on other groups of plants. ==Herbert Medalists== A full list of those awarded the Herbert Medal is given on the International Bulb Society website, and in ''Herbertia'' (1937–1988).[http://dafflibrary.org/wp-content/uploads/Mitsch-Herbert-Medal-optv2.pdf The Herbert Medal] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20061004033711/http://bulbsociety.org/ The International Bulb Society] {{DEFAULTSORT:Herbert Medal, The}} [[Category:Botany]]

{{italic title}} {{Infobox book | italic title = <!--(see above)--> | name = The Rap Year Book: The Most Important Rap Song From Every Year Since 1979, Discussed, Debated, and Deconstructed | image = | image_size = | alt = | caption = | author = [[Shea Serrano]] | audio_read_by = | title_orig = | orig_lang_code = | title_working = | translator = | illustrator = [[Arturo Torres (artist)|Arturo Torres]] | country = United States | language = English | series = | release_number = | subject = [[Rap]] | genre = [[Music criticism]], [[music history]] | set_in = | publisher = [[Abrams Image]] | publisher2 = | pub_date = October 13, 2015 | english_pub_date = | published = | media_type = Paperback | pages = 240 | awards = | isbn = 1-4197-1818-5 | isbn_note = | oclc = | dewey = | congress = | preceded_by = | followed_by = | native_wikisource = | wikisource = | notes = | exclude_cover = | website = https://www.abramsbooks.com/product/rap-year-book_9781419718182/ }} '''''The Rap Year Book: The Most Important Rap Song From Every Year Since 1979, Discussed, Debated, and Deconstructed''''' is a 2015 ''[[New York Times]]'' best-selling book written by [[Shea Serrano]] and illustrated by [[Arturo Torres (artist)|Arturo Torres]].
==Development== ''The Rap Year Book'' followed Serrano's 2013 project with [[Houston]] rapper [[Bun B]], ''Bun B's Rap Coloring and Activity Book''.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Bacher|first1=Danielle|title=Q&A: Bun B on the 'Incredible Journey' of Creating His Hip-Hop Coloring Book|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/q-a-bun-b-on-the-incredible-journey-of-creating-his-hip-hop-coloring-book-20130618|accessdate=26 August 2016|work=Rolling Stone|date=June 18, 2013}}</ref> ''The Rap Year Book'' took 15 months to develop,<ref name=":4">{{cite news|last1=Euse|first1=Erica|title=How 'The Rap Year Book' Breaks Down the Most Important Rap Songs for Each Year Since 1979|url=http://www.complex.com/style/2015/10/a-look-inside-the-rap-year-book|accessdate=27 August 2016|work=Complex|date=October 12, 2015}}</ref> and was still without an illustrator three months before the book's due date. Serrano encountered eventual collaborator Torres via a flyer Torres had designed announcing a performance by [[Dallas]] rap group The Outfit, Texas; Serrano told ''[[Texas Monthly]]'' that on seeing Torres's work, he thought immediately, "This is the exact style that I’m trying to find."<ref>{{cite news|last1=Solomon|first1=Dan|title=Music Monday: Shea Serrano On 'The Rap Yearbook' And His Houston Hip Hop Playlist|url=http://www.texasmonthly.com/the-daily-post/music-monday-shea-serrano-on-the-rap-yearbook-and-his-houston-hip-hop-playlist/|accessdate=23 August 2016|work=Texas Monthly|date=12 October 2015}}</ref> Serrano contacted the group's management asking for information about who had made their flyer and eventually tracked Torres down on social media; Torres agreed to work on the book.
==Publication== ''The Rap Year Book'' was published on October 13, 2015, by [[Abrams Image]].<ref name=":0">{{cite news|last1=Schiewe|first1=Jessie|title=Here's How One Writer Spent Way Too Long Deciding the Best Rap Song Every Year from 1979 to 2014 {{!}} NOISEY|url=http://noisey.vice.com/blog/shea-serrano-interview-rap-yearbook|accessdate=26 August 2016|work=Noisey|publisher=Vice|date=October 9, 2015}}</ref> It is 240 pages with 150 full-color illustrations.<ref>{{cite web|title=Rap Year Book The Most Important Rap Song From Every Year Since 1979, Discussed, Debated, and Deconstructed|url=https://www.abramsbooks.com/product/rap-year-book_9781419718182/|website=Abrams Books|accessdate=30 May 2017}}</ref>
==Format== The book is structured around essays by Serrano selecting the most important rap song for every year from 1979 to 2014.<ref name=":4" /> His text is accompanied by illustrations by Torres, "bright, colorful, and offbeat cartoons...featuring depictions of [[Kanye]] and [[Jay-Z]] on a movie poster, [[Dr. Dre]] in scrubs, [[Drake (musician)|Drake]] using a pottery wheel, and more."<ref name=":1">{{cite news|last1=Fitzgerald|first1=Colin|title='The Rap Year Book' Reformats Hip-Hop History|url=http://www.popmatters.com/review/the-rap-year-book-by-shea-serrano/|accessdate=23 August 2016|work=PopMatters|date=October 29, 2016}}</ref> [[Ice-T]] wrote the book's preface,<ref name=":0" /> and critics, including [[Wesley Morris]] and [[Jessica Hopper]], contributed short rebuttals arguing for alternative choices as the most important song of a given year.<ref name=":2" />
==Reception==
===Sales=== Propelled by Serrano's engagement with his enthusiastic [[Twitter]] following,<ref name=":3">{{cite news|last1=Locke|first1=Charley|title=How One Man and His Twitter Army Stormed the Bestseller List|url=https://www.wired.com/2015/10/rap-year-book-best-seller/|accessdate=23 August 2016|work=Wired|date=October 25, 2015}}</ref> ''The Rap Year Book'' repeatedly ranked on 2015 ''The New York Times'' best-seller lists.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Tiffany|first1=Kaitlyn|title=The Rap Yearbook author Shea Serrano on building a tiny utopia on Twitter|url=https://www.theverge.com/2016/7/6/12067954/shea-serrano-the-rap-yearbook-twitter-interview|accessdate=23 August 2016|work=The Verge|date=6 July 2016}}</ref> The book's first pressing of 20,000 copies sold out in pre-orders before ''The Rap Year Book'' even hit shelves;<ref>{{cite news|last1=Crucchiola|first1=Jordan|title=The King Of Twitter: Shea Serrano Is Our New Favorite Internet Hero|url=https://www.good.is/articles/shea-serrano-basketball-and-other-things|accessdate=23 August 2016|work=GOOD|date=30 May 2016}}</ref> a mock "feud" on Twitter between Serrano and [[Books-a-Million]] sold out the retailer's stock of the book in one day, and crashed the company's website in the process.<ref name=":3" />
===Reviews=== ''[[PopMatters]]'' reviewed the book as "both educationally useful and shamelessly fun...tailor-made to counter every criticism levied against routine, overly generalized music retrospectives."<ref name=":1" /> In the ''[[Los Angeles Review of Books]]'', Oliver Wang said that while Serrano's essays take a position on what constitutes the most important song of each year, "he doesn’t browbeat his reader into agreement; he writes confidently but not condescendingly. More importantly, the main pleasure in reading ''The Rap Year Book'' isn’t in agreeing with Serrano’s choices but rather in following the elliptical paths he takes to explain them."<ref name=":2">{{cite news|last1=Wang|first1=Oliver|title=Top Five, Dead or Alive|url=https://lareviewofbooks.org/article/top-five-dead-or-alive/|accessdate=26 August 2016|work=Los Angeles Review of Books|date=February 6, 2016}}</ref>
==Adaptation== In July 2017, Serrano announced that AMC would produce ''The Rap Year Book'' as a 6-part television documentary series with The Roots as executive producers.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Darville|first1=Jordan|title=Shea Serrano’s The Rap Yearbook To Be Made Into An AMC Documentary Series|url=http://www.thefader.com/2017/07/31/the-rap-yearbook-documentary|accessdate=29 July 2017|work=The Fader|date=April 2, 2018}}</ref>

{{refimprove|date=March 2018}}
'''Young Lives''' is an international research project on childhood poverty that was established in 2000 and is coordinated by a team based at the [[University of Oxford]]'s Department of International Development (Queen Elizabeth House), [[Great Britain]].
Young Lives, by its declaration, is tracing the changing lives of 12,000 children in Ethiopia, India (Andhra Pradesh), Peru and Vietnam over a 15-year period. This is the time frame set by the UN to assess progress towards the [[Millennium Development Goals]]. Through interviews, group work and case studies with the children, their parents, teachers, community representatives and others, the project is collecting information not only about their material and social circumstances, but also their perspectives on their lives and aspirations for the futures, set against the environmental and social realities of their communities.
Young Lives is following two groups of children in each country: * 2,000 children who were born in 2001-02 * 1,000 children who were born in 1994-95.
These groups provide insights into every phase of childhood. The younger children are being tracked from infancy to their mid-teens and the older children through into adulthood, when some will become parents themselves. When this is matched with information gathered about their parents, it is possible to reveal much about the inter generational transmission of poverty, how families on the margins move in and out of poverty, and the policies that can make a real difference to their lives.
The research concentrates on 4 countries: [[Ethiopia]], [[India]] ([[Andhra Pradesh]]), [[Peru]] and [[Vietnam]], chosen because they reflect a wide range of cultural, political, geographical and social contexts. They face some of the common issues experienced by developing countries, such as high debt burden, post-conflict reconstruction and adverse environmental conditions such as drought and flood. By covering these countries, Young Lives aims to reveal patterns, commonalities and differences in four very different contexts where childhood - especially childhood poverty - is changing.
The project is core-funded by the UK [[Department for International Development]] (DFID), with sub-studies funded by [[International Development Research Center]] (IDRC) (in [[Ethiopia]]), [[UNICEF]] (in [[India]]), [[Irish Aid]] (in Vietnam) and the [[Bernard van Leer Foundation]] (in [[India]] and [[Peru]]).<ref>[http://www.cls.ioe.ac.uk/page.aspx?&sitesectionid=904&sitesectiontitle=Young+Lives Centre for Longitudinal Studies]</ref>
== Declared objectives == * provide good-quality information about the lives of children in different contexts; * identify ways poverty affects children’s lives and their future prospects; * better understand how poverty is transferred from one generation to another; * trace linkages between key policy changes and children’s well-being; * promote effective and sustainable poverty reduction policies; * build capacity for and understanding of longitudinal research in the four study countries.
